thread.title: Fifth dead person in two weeks found in NYC subway system
thread.title_full: Fifth dead person in two weeks found in NYC subway system

author: THOMAS TRACY
title: Fifth dead person in two weeks found in NYC subway system
text:
61-year-old man is fifth dead person found in NYC subway system in two weeks Fifth dead person in two weeks found in NYC subway system A 61-year-old man was found dead on a train rumbling through Lower Manhattan Tuesday — the fifth person to die on the city’s subway system in two weeks, officials said. (Nance, Catherine) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   1:45 PM 
A 61-year-old man was found dead on a train rumbling through Lower Manhattan Tuesday — the fifth person to die on the city’s subway system in two weeks, officials said. 
All four victims were not hit by trains, they noted. 
Commuters on a Queens-bound J train found the man slumped over on his seat as the train entered the Broad St. station in Lower Manhattan. 
The man died at the scene, officials said. His name was not immediately disclosed. 
Investigators believe that the man died of natural causes, possibly a heart attack, police sources said. 
An autopsy has been slated to determine how he died. 
On Friday, a 24-year-old man was found unconscious on an A train leaving the Jay St./MetroTech station in Brooklyn Heights. 
FDNY EMTs rushed the man to Brooklyn Hospital, where he died. Again, police found no evidence of foul play. 
On March 13, maintenance workers found a man dead near the subway tracks just north of the W. 103rd St. station near Central Park West on the Upper West Side, officials said. The man had been dead for a week, cops determined. 
Two days earlier, on March 11, a homeless man died after being found unconscious on subway tracks in Harlem, officials said. 
The victim was discovered sprawled on the downtown tracks of the 6 train 125th St. station at about 1:15 a.m. 
Finally, on March 7, a man with no ID was found facedown on the floor of an E train at the World Trade Center, officials said. He later died at New York-Presbyterian Lower Manhattan Hospital, cops said. 
None of the deaths have been deemed suspicious, officials said. Tags:
